sections.heading: When to Use Keigo
sections.content:
Keigo should be used based on social relationships, situations, and contexts. Understanding when to use keigo is as important as knowing the forms themselves. Use keigo to show respect to superiors, maintain professional distance, and navigate formal situations appropriately.

With boss: 部長がおっしゃいました (keigo) "The director said" With friend: 友達が言った (casual) "My friend said" Context determines usage

children.heading: Superior to you
children.content: Boss/Manager: Use keigo 先生 (teacher): Use keigo 先輩 (senior): Use keigo お客様 (customer): Use keigo 年上 (elders): Use keigo Higher status requires respect

children.heading: Equal or lower
children.content: 同僚 (colleague): Polite form usually sufficient 後輩 (junior): Polite or casual 友達 (friend): Casual 家族 (family): Casual (except formal occasions) Less formality needed

children.heading: Always use keigo for
children.content: Speaking to superiors 部長、この資料をご覧になりますか。 "Director, will you look at this document?" Speaking about superiors to others 部長がおっしゃっていました。 "The director was saying..." Client/customer interactions お客様がお待ちです。 "The customer is waiting."

children.heading: When representing company
children.content: To external people 弊社の山田が参ります。 "Our Yamada will come." (humble) Lower your company Raise other company Professional standard

children.heading: Always use keigo
children.content: Retail: お客様、こちらでございます。 "Customer, it's this one." Restaurant: ご注文をお伺いします。 "I'll take your order." Hotel: お部屋へご案内いたします。 "I'll guide you to your room." Service = keigo

children.heading: Use keigo in
children.content: Job interviews Presentations Ceremonies First meetings Official events Business negotiations Formal context = keigo

children.heading: Generally use with
children.content: Significantly older people Your seniors (先輩) People you just met Authority figures Age/seniority → respect

children.heading: Can be casual with
children.content: Close friends (same age) Younger siblings Close colleagues (after rapport) Very casual settings Relationship allows casual

children.heading: Family at home
children.content: お母さん、ご飯食べた？ Unnatural with parents at home お母さん、ご飯食べた？ Natural casual form Home = casual usually

children.heading: Close friends
children.content: Unnatural: 友達がいらっしゃった Natural: 友達が来た "Friend came" Over-keigo creates distance

children.heading: About yourself
children.content: Wrong: 私がいらっしゃる ⚠️ Correct: 私が行く/参る ✓ "I go" Don't elevate yourself

children.heading: First meeting
children.content: 初めまして。田中と申します。 "Nice to meet you. I'm called Tanaka." (humble) Start formal Adjust based on cues

children.heading: After building rapport
children.content: With colleagues: Formal → Polite → Casual (over time) With friends: Can shift to casual faster Relationship evolves

children.heading: Talking to outsiders
children.content: About your boss to client: 部長の山田が参ります (humble) "Our director Yamada will come" Lower your in-group Raise out-group

children.heading: Internal communication
children.content: Within company to boss: 部長がおっしゃいました (respectful) "The director said" Maintain internal hierarchy

children.heading: Emails to superiors
children.content: 件名: 報告書について 部長、お疲れ様です。 資料をお送りいたします。 Use keigo in business emails

children.heading: Formal documents
children.content: Reports Applications Official letters Written formality = keigo

children.heading: Always required
children.content: Restaurants Hotels Retail stores Banks Hospitals Customer = superior Always use keigo

children.heading: Students to teachers
children.content: 先生、質問がございます。 "Teacher, I have a question." Always use keigo Shows respect

children.heading: Teachers to students
children.content: Can use polite form Less keigo required But maintain dignity

children.heading: Business meetings
children.content: お時間をいただき、ありがとうございます。 "Thank you for your time." ご検討いただけますでしょうか。 "Could you consider it?" Professional keigo essential

children.heading: Presentations
children.content: 本日はお集まりいただき、 ありがとうございます。 "Thank you for gathering today." Formal audience = keigo

children.heading: Guest in home/office
children.content: Use polite language Don't be too casual Show respect as guest お邪魔します "Excuse me for intruding"

children.heading: Business calls
children.content: お世話になっております。 "Thank you for your continued support." Always use keigo Can't see status Be safe with formality

children.heading: Business contexts
children.content: Emails: Use keigo Slack/Teams: Polite minimum With superiors: Full keigo Context matters

children.heading: Reading the room
children.content: Start formal Observe others Match their level Don't shift too quickly 空気を読む (read the air)

children.heading: Safe to use keigo
children.content: ✓ Job interviews ✓ Meeting clients ✓ Speaking to strangers ✓ Formal events ✓ Service interactions ✓ Business emails When in doubt, use keigo

children.heading: Can be casual
children.content: ✓ Close friends ✓ Family (usually) ✓ Peers after rapport ✓ Very informal settings Clear casual relationship

children.heading: Basic
children.content: Meeting boss: 部長、おはようございます。 "Director, good morning." Helping customer: お客様、こちらへどうぞ。 "Customer, this way please." With friend: 昨日、何した？ "What did you do yesterday?"

children.heading: Intermediate
children.content: ビジネスミーティング: 本日はお忙しいところお時間を いただき、誠にありがとうございます。 弊社の新しい企画についてご説明 させていただきます。 "Business meeting: Thank you very much for your time today despite being busy. I will explain about our company's new project." 同僚との会話: 昨日の会議、どうだった？ 部長、何かおっしゃってた？ "Conversation with colleague: How was yesterday's meeting? Did the director say anything?"
